option.name: description
option.value: Small exercises to get you used to reading and writing Rust code!

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
### Variables
Here you'll learn about simple variables.
#### Book Sections
- [Variables and Mutability](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch03-01-variables-and-mutability.html)

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
The declaration on line 2 is missing a keyword that is needed in Rust to create a new variable binding.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
The compiler message is saying that Rust cannot infer the type that the variable binding `x` has with what is given here. What happens if you annotate line 5 with a type annotation? What if you give `x` a value? What if you do both? What type should `x` be, anyway? What if `x` is the same type as 10? What if it's a different type?

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
In Rust, variable bindings are immutable by default. But here we're trying to reassign a different value to `x`! There's a keyword we can use to make a variable binding mutable instead.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
Oops! In this exercise, we have a variable binding that we've created on line 5, and we're trying to use it on line 6, but we haven't given it a value. We can't print out something that isn't there; try giving x a value! This is an error that can cause bugs that's very easy to make in any programming language -- thankfully the Rust compiler has caught this for us!

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
### If
`if`, the most basic type of control flow, is what you'll learn here.
#### Book Sections
- [Control Flow - if expressions](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch03-05-control-flow.html#if-expressions)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Complete this function to return the bigger number! Do not use: - `return` - another function call - additional variables
It's possible to do this in one line if you would like! Some similar examples from other languages: - In C(++) this would be: `a > b ? a : b` - In Python this would be: `a if a > b else b` Remember in Rust that: - the `if` condition does not need to be surrounded by parentheses - `if` / `else` conditionals are expressions - Each condition is followed by a `{}` block.

option.name: text
option.value: // put code of your task here

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
### Functions
Here, you'll learn how to write functions and how Rust's compiler can trace things way back.
#### Book Sections
- [How Functions Work](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch03-03-how-functions-work.html)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
This main function is calling a function that it expects to exist, but the function doesn't exist. It expects this function to have the name `call_me`. It expects this function to not take any arguments and not return a value. Sounds a lot like `main`, doesn't it?

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
Rust requires that all parts of a function's signature have type annotations, but `call_me` is missing the type annotation of `num`.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
This time, the function *declaration* is okay, but there's something wrong with the place where we're calling the function.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile! This store is having a sale where if the price is an even number, you get 10 (money unit) off, but if it's an odd number, it's 3 (money unit) less.
The error message points to line 12 and says it expects a type after the `->`. This is where the function's return type should be -- take a look at the `is_even` function for an example!

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
This is a really common error that can be fixed by removing one character. It happens because Rust distinguishes between expressions and statements: expressions return a value based on its operand, and statements simply return a () type which behaves just like `void` in C/C++ language. We want to return a value of `i32` type from the `square` function, but it is returning a `()` type... They are not the same. There are two solutions: 1. Add a `return` ahead of `num * num;` 2. remove `;`, make it to be `num * num`

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
### Primitive Types
Rust has a couple of basic types that are directly implemented into the compiler. In this section, we'll go through the most important ones.
#### Book Sections
- [Data Types](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch03-02-data-types.html)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Fill in the rest of the line that has code missing!
No hints, there's no tricks, just get used to typing these :)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Fill in the rest of the line that has code missing!
No hints, there's no tricks, just get used to typing these :)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Create an array with at least 100 elements.
There's a shorthand to initialize Arrays with a certain size that does not require you to type in 100 items (but you certainly can if you want!). For example, you can do: ```rust let array = ["Are we there yet?"; 10]; ```
Bonus: what are some other things you could have that would return true for `a.len() >= 100`?

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Get a slice out of Array so that the `if` statement returns `true`.
Take a look at the Understanding Ownership -> Slices -> Other Slices section of the book: https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch04-03-slices.html and use the starting and ending indices of the items in the Array that you want to end up in the slice. If you're curious why the right hand of the `==` comparison does not have an ampersand for a reference since the left hand side is a reference, take a look at the Deref coercions section of the book: https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch15-02-deref.html

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Destructure the `cat` tuple so that the println will work.
Take a look at the Data Types -> The Tuple Type section of the book: https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch03-02-data-types.html#the-tuple-type Particularly the part about destructuring (second to last example in the section). You'll need to make a pattern to bind `name` and `age` to the appropriate parts of the tuple. You can do it!!

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Use a tuple index to access the second element of `numbers`. You can put this right into the `println!`.
While you could use a destructuring `let` for the tuple here, try indexing into it instead, as explained in the last example of the Data Types -> The Tuple Type section of the book: https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch03-02-data-types.html#the-tuple-type Now you have another tool in your toolbox!

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
### Tests
Going out of order from the book to cover tests -- many of the following exercises will ask you to make tests pass!
#### Book Sections
- [Writing Tests](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch11-01-writing-tests.html)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Tests are important to ensure that your code does what you think it should do. This test has a problem with it -- make the test compile! Make the test pass! Make the test fail!
You don't even need to write any code to test -- you can just test values and run that, even though you wouldn't do that in real life :) `assert!` is a macro that needs an argument. Depending on the value of the argument, `assert!` will do nothing (in which case the test will pass) or `assert!` will panic (in which case the test will fail). So try giving different values to `assert!` and see which ones compile, which ones pass, and which ones fail :)

option.name: text
option.value: // put code of your task here

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
This test has a problem with it -- make the test compile! Make the test pass! Make the test fail!
Like the previous exercise, you don't need to write any code to get this test to compile and run. `assert_eq!` is a macro that takes two arguments and compares them. Try giving it two values that are equal! Try giving it two arguments that are different! Try giving it two values that are of different types! Try switching which argument comes first and which comes second!

option.name: text
option.value: // put code of your task here

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
This test isn't testing our function -- make it do that in such a way that the test passes. Then write a second test that tests whether we get the result we expect to get when we call `is_even(5)`.
You can call a function right where you're passing arguments to `assert!` -- so you could do something like `assert!(having_fun())`. If you want to check that you indeed get false, you can negate the result of what you're doing using `!`, like `assert!(!having_fun())`.

option.name: text
option.value: // put code of your task here

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
### Strings
Rust has two string types, a string slice (`&str`) and an owned string (`String`). We're not going to dictate when you should use which one, but we'll show you how to identify and create them, as well as use them.
#### Book Sections
- [Strings](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch08-02-strings.html)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile without changing the function signature!
The `current_favorite_color` function is currently returning a string slice with the `'static` lifetime. We know this because the data of the string lives in our code itself -- it doesn't come from a file or user input or another program -- so it will live as long as our program lives. But it is still a string slice. There's one way to create a `String` by converting a string slice covered in the Strings chapter of the book, and another way that uses the `From` trait.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile without changing the function signature!
Yes, it would be really easy to fix this by just changing the value bound to `word` to be a string slice instead of a `String`, wouldn't it?? There is a way to add one character to line 6, though, that will coerce the `String` into a string slice.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
### Modules
In this section we'll give you an introduction to Rust's module system.
#### Book Sections
- [The Module System](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch07-02-modules-and-use-to-control-scope-and-privacy.html)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
Everything is private in Rust by default -- but there's a keyword we can use to make something public! The compiler error should point to the thing that needs to be public.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
The delicious_snacks module is trying to present an external interface (the `fruit` and `veggie` constants) that is different than its internal structure (the `fruits` and `veggies` modules and associated constants). It's almost there except for one keyword missing for each constant.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
### Macros
Rust's macro system is very powerful, but also kind of difficult to wrap your head around. We're not going to teach you how to write your own fully-featured modules, instead we'll show you how to use and create them.
#### Book Sections
- [Macros](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch19-06-macros.html) - [The Little Book of Rust Macros](https://danielkeep.github.io/tlborm/book/index.html)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
When you call a macro, you need to add something special compared to a regular function call. If you're stuck, take a look at what's inside `my_macro`.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
Macros don't quite play by the same rules as the rest of Rust, in terms of what's available where. Unlike other things in Rust, the order of "where you define a macro" versus "where you use it" actually matters.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile, without taking the macro out of the module!
In order to use a macro outside of its module, you need to do something special to the module to lift the macro out into its parent. The same trick also works on "extern crate" statements for crates that have exported macros, if you've seen any of those around.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
You only need to add a single character to make this compile. The way macros are written, it wants to see something between each "macro arm", so it can separate them.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
### Move Semantics
These exercises are adapted from [pnkfelix](https://github.com/pnkfelix)'s [Rust Tutorial](https://pnkfelix.github.io/rust-examples-icfp2014/) -- Thank you Felix!!!
#### Book Sections
For this section, the book links are especially important.
- [Ownership](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch04-01-what-is-ownership.html) - [Reference and borrowing](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch04-02-references-and-borrowing.html)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile!
So you've got the "cannot borrow immutable local variable `vec1` as mutable" error on line 11, right? The fix for this is going to be adding one keyword, and the addition is NOT on line 11 where the error is.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile without changing line 10!
So `vec0` is being *moved* into the function `fill_vec` when we call it on line 7, which means it gets dropped at the end of `fill_vec`, which means we can't use `vec0` again on line 10 (or anywhere else in `main` after the `fill_vec` call for that matter). We could fix this in a few ways, try them all! 1. Make another, separate version of the data that's in `vec0` and pass that to `fill_vec` instead. 2. Make `fill_vec` borrow its argument instead of taking ownership of it, and then copy the data within the function in order to return an owned `Vec` 3. Make `fill_vec` *mutably* borrow its argument (which will need to be mutable), modify it directly, then not return anything. Then you can get rid of `vec1` entirely -- note that this will change what gets printed by the first `println!`

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Make me compile without adding new lines -- just changing existing lines! (no lines with multiple semicolons necessary!)
The difference between this one and the previous ones is that the first line of `fn fill_vec` that had `let mut vec = vec;` is no longer there. You can, instead of adding that line back, add `mut` in one place that will change an existing binding to be a mutable binding instead of an immutable one :)

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Write your task text here.
Hints can be added anywhere in task text: type "hint" and press Tab.

option.name: text
